Notre 
Dom
M ofre e 
af a giance ... 
The University of Notre Dame, once an ob­scure school in the northern Indiana wilderness, has become inlittle more than a century a great institution of higher learning, recognized the world over for the high caliber of its teaching, research, and public service. 
Founded in 1842 by the Holy Cross Fathers, a French missionary community, Notre Dame is now governed by a predominantly lay Board of Trustees one of several evolutionary changes which have kept the University among the pioneers in American Catholic higher education. The chairman of the Board of Trustees is Ed­mund A. Stephan, an alumnus of the University and a Chicago, 111., attorney. The president of Notre Dame is the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, C.S.C., who has served since 1952 as the Uni­versity's sixteenth president. 
v _ Administration Building (36) • **J 
The first president of the University, the Rev. Edward F. Sorin, C.S.C., whose statue stands at the beginning of the Administration Building mall, began his school for boys on the site of a log chapel. A replica of this Tog chapel, which served as a missionary outpost of the first priest ordained in the United States, is found today on campps, amidst more than 80 other campus structures, highlighted by the magnificentNotre Dame Memorial Library. 
Now well into its second century of service to the nation and the Church, the University consists of a Graduate School, the Notre Dame Law School (the oldest Catholic law school in 
the UnitedStates), and four undergraduate col­leges:Arts and Letters,Science,Engineering,and Business Administration. Specialized units with­in the University include the Lobund Laboratory, an internationally known facility for radiation chemistry research; the Mediaeval Institute; the Jacques Maritain Center, the Center for the Study of Man in Contemporary Society; the Institute for Advanced Religious Studies; and the Center for Continuing Education. 
Father Hesburgh heads a faculty of 604 per­sons who hold advanced degrees from virtually every major university in the world. Laymen predominate on the faculty which numbers about 55 priests and religious, most of them members of the Congregation of Holy Cross. While Notre Dame is Catholic in its origin, tra­ditions, philosophy and atmosphere, other de­nominations have always been represented in its faculty and student body. 
Research is an important mission of every great university, and grants totaling more than $7,000,000 annually are testimony of the qual­ity ofNotre Dame'sresearch programs. Lobund scientists are engaged in a variety of projects dealing with cancer, heart disease, nutrition and germfree human surgery. The University's research in radiation chemistry, the most exten­sive underway on any college or university campus, is centered in a new $2,200,000 Radi­ation Research Building erected by the U. S. 
Atomic Energy Commission. Other major areas of research include nuclear physics, polymer chemistry, international relations, aeronautical and metallurgical engineering and the social sciences. Expediting all of Notre Dame's re­search projects is a new Computing Center, built around a UNIVAC 1107. 
" V Nieuwland Science'Hqll f52) y.»» 
A university exists primarily, of course, for its students. Notre Dame's 7,200 students, known both for their scholarship and their spirit, repre­sent every state of the Union and fifty-two foreign countries In recent years graduating seniors have compiled an impressive record in nationwide fellowship competitions conducted by the Woodrow Wilson, Danforth and National Science Foundations. 
Approximately 4,700 students live on the campus, and nearly one-third of the University's buildings provide living, eating and recrearion­al facilities for them. Most of the undergrad­uates live in Notre Dame's nineteen residence hails, each with its own chapel. They eat in the University's two large dining halls which serve approximately 16,000 meals daily. More than 1,200 students are members of the Army, Navy, and Air Force ROTC units on the campus. The Stepan Center and the LaFortune Student Cen­ter provide excellent facilities for dances, other extracurricular activities and special events. 
Religion has never been "extracurricular" at Notre Dame. Sacred Heart Church, the Grotto of Our Lady of Lourdes and the many chapels 
and shrines all serve as reminders that religion and morality are the mark of the Notre Dame man. Students attending the University have an unparalleled opportunity for spiritual develop­ment. Courses in theology (not required of non-Catholic students) are included in the curricula of all the colleges. For it is Notre Dame's con­viction, today as always, that it is not enough for a University to develop professional com­petence in a young man. To it mustbe added a sense of moral and social responsibility which will fortify his family, professional and civic life. Notre Dame students are heavily commit­ted to the Church's social apostdate, which re­ceived renewed emphasis during the Second Vatican Council. During a recent school year some 500 students were involved in tutoring disadvantaged youngsters in the South Bend area, and the percentage of Notre Dame grad­uates who enter the Peace Corps has been re­markably high. 
Notre Dame's thousand acre campus, with its twin lakes and many wooded areas, is vir­tually a self-sustaining city with its own post office, power plant, television and radio sta­tions and campus hotel. The Morris Inn. The University, with a full-time staff of 2,285, is one of the largest employers in the area. Its 

W ,. to-*. m 
current annual operating budget is about $35% million. However, Notre Dame's endowment of$60 million isone of the smallest'among the nation's major private universities. 
In September, 1967, Notre Dame launched an ambitious $52 million, five-year program designed to achieve development in depth of the University, particularly on the graduate level. Principle elements are the University's endowment for faculty salaries, its graduate and research programs, and its new campus construction. The program is called "SUMMA: Notre Dame's Greatest Challenge.". 
-HU.I 
O-Shaughriessy. Wall of; Liberal 
'-yi-A \ * A /"CZV* 
OF SPECIAL INTEREST 

Some of Notre Dame's buildings and facilities, because of their historic char­acter, recent construction or for other reasons, are of special interest to visi­tors. Among them are: 
The Administration Building (36), surmounted by its famed golden dome and statue of Our Lady, was erected in 1879 after fire destroyed its predecessor. Also known as the Main Build­ing, it houses the office of the president and the other principal administrative offices of the University. Murals by Luigi Gregori depicting the life of Christopher Columbus can be seen along its first-floor corridor. It is a tradition that students do not use the front steps of the building until the weekend of their graduation. 
Sacred Heart Church (29) is the center of cam­pus religious life. Built in 1871, its Gothic spire encloses the oldest carillon in North America. Of particular beauty are its stained glass windows imported from LeMans in France, the baroque altar in Our Lady Chapel, 
'' Center, for >Continuing-Education (81} 
and 

and the "Pieta" by the late Prof Ivan Mestro­
vic of Notre Dame. The body of the late John Cardinal O'Hara, CSC, former president of the University, is interred in a chapel to the left of the main altar. 
The Grotto of Our Lady of Lourdes (28) is a replica of the world-famous shrine at Lourdes in France. Completed in 1896, it is a center of devotion where students, faculty members and visitors pause to pray day and night The Confraternity of the Immaculate Conception of Our Lady of Lourdes, whose offices are lo­cated to the rear of the Grotto, distributes Lourdes water throughout the United States. 
Notre Dame Memorial Library [72)' 

The O'Shaughnessy Hall of Liberal and Fine Arts (56) is the home of Notre Dame's College of Arts and Letters. The stained glass windows in its Great Hall represent -the seven liberal 
arts of the ancients. O'Shaughnessy Hall houses the University Gallery whose fine col­lection of painting and sculpture can be viewed from 1 to 5 p.m daily The building, dedicated in 1953, is the gift of Mr. I. A. O'Shaughnessy and the late Mrs. O'Shaugh­nessy of St. Paul, Minn 
Nieuwland Science Hall (52) provides class­rooms and laboratories for Notre Dame's chem­istry, physics and mathematics departments. Occupying a portion of the building is an "atom smasher" which is central to the Uni­versity's nuclear physics research. The build­ing, which was dedicated in 1953, honors the late Rev Julius A.Nieuwland, CS.C ,who de­veloped the formula for synthetic rubber and founded THE AMERICAN MIDLAND NATURAL­IST which is published by the University. 
1 iggajsiig 
Computing Center and * Mathematics Building:,^4) 
The Notre Dame Memorial Library (72), which opened in the fall of 1963, stands at the cen­ter of a new east campus quadrangle The thir­teen-story building has a capacity of two million volumes and can seat nearly half of the Uni­versity's undergraduates at one time. The col­lege library occupies the first two floors, and the tower section of the building is devoted to graduate materials in the various academic disciplines and to several of Notre Dame's specialized research units. 
Lewis Hall (80), a residence hall for nuns study­ing for advanced degrees at Notre Dame, is the newest of the University's eighteen student residences. The four-story building, which ac­commodates approximately 140 nuns and in­cludes kitchen facilities and an enclosed court­yard, is a gift of the Frank J Lewis Founda­tion, Chicago, Illinois The Hammes Notre Dame Bookstore (19), ii addition to handling texts and other materials for students, has available campus souvenirs, religious articles and other items of interest to visitors. The bookstore's hours are 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Saturday. Dedicated 

in 1955, the building is the gift of Mr. Romy Hammes, Kankakee, III and the late Mrs. Hammes. 
The Center for Continuing Education (81), is the campus focal point for conferences, seminars and other specialized programs which provide an opportunity for scholars, businessmen and professional people to keep abreast with ad­vances in their respective fields. Constructed through a $116 million grant from the W. K. Kellogg Foundation, Battle Creek, Mich , the Center provides twenty-two seminar rooms, an auditorium, audio-visiual center, theater, and other facilities. 
The University Dining Halls serve the student body and provide banquet facilities for up to one thousand guests. The North Dining Hall (60), which opened in 1957, provides six at­tractive dining rooms and basement storage space for forty carloads of food. A cafeteria, open to visitors, is located in the South Dining Hall (17) Its hours are 7 to 10:30 a.m , 11 a.m. to 1:30 p.m., and 4-45 to 7 p.m. Snacks are available at The Huddle, in LaFortune Student Center, from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m 
The Morris Inn (21) is an air-conditioned, 92­
room hotel operated by the University at the 
entrance to the campus. It is the gift of the 
late Ernest M. Morris and Mrs. Morris of South 
Bend, Ind. Alumni and friends of Notre Dame 
are always welcome at The Morris Inn. Its 
dining room is open from 7 to 10:30 a.m., 
from 11:30 am to 2 p m , and from 5:30 un­
til 8.30 p.m. 
The new Athletic and Convocation Center (79), with itstwin arenas totaling morethan 400,000 square feet, is the hub of campus sports com­petition. One arena has a seating capacity of 12,000 for basketball, convocations and other special events. The other includes an indoor track, a baseball infield, an ice skating rink and facilities for a variety of sports. 
"Athletic-and Convocation Center (79) 
c UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME, 1965

St. Mary’s Supplement.................................................................................................153 
The information contained in this directory was compiled by the Personnel Office and the Student Government of the University of Notre Dame. Student addresses are those that were turned in at registration or corrected at the Student Government Office before October 2, 1968. Persons wishing to make corrections should sendtheir name,address and the correction to either the Student Government Office or Personnel Office, c/o Student—Staff—Faculty Directory. If sufficient corrections are received, a supplement to this Directory will be published later thisyear. 
-1­
Operating 


Operating Instructions for Centrex 
NOTRE DAME AND ST. MARY'S CAMPUS 
CALLS—Dial LAST four numerals. 
LOCAL CALLS—Dial “9” then the seven digit number. 
CAMPUS INFORMATION-# not listed in direc-tory-Dial "O". 
ST. MARY'S INFORMATION-Consult St. Mary's 
Directory—ifnot listed Dial “O”. 
LOCAL INFORMATION-Dial "9"-then Dial 113. 
REPAIR AND ASSISTANCE—If your telephone is not working properly, or you need assistance with a 
call-Dial "O". 
TO TRANSFER CALLS-Incoming calls ONLY 
may be transferred. Depress the receiver hook one time and release; the operator will answer and you can giveher yourrequest. 
DIALING CAMPUS NUMBERS FROM OFF CAM­
PUS—DialALL seven numerals.Ifyou do notknow the number, dial the Notre Dame University listed number 283-6011. 
LONG DISTANCE-STUDENTS-To reach the 
Long Distance Operator—Dial “9” then “O”.Only the following calls may be placed:Credit Card Collect 
ALL OTHERS-Dial "9" then "0"-give the operator the area code, telephone number, and the 
name of the person you wish to contact. GIVE THE OPERATOR 283 AND THE NUMBER ASSIGNED TO YOU when the operator asks for your number. 
DIRECT DIALING—Dial “9”-Dial “l”-then dial the area code and telephone number of the distant party. 
DIRECTORY CHANGES—Should be reported as they occur to Personnel Department. Changes in­clude additions, deletions, number changes, correc­tions in Directory, etc. 
TO REPORT AN EMERGENCY-Dial “O” operator and give location of accident, name of injured person, if known, and extension of calling party. Calling party should stay on the line until the operatorhas made arrangements. 
Individuals in need of ambulance service for reason ofillness should contact aprivate ambulance. Suggested ambulances are: 
Hickey 234-4155 Bilancio-Guisinger 232-5853 
CONFERENCE CALLS—Can be placed from anystation on campus by dialing “5” for the conference operator. It is possible to have five conferees on one conference call. 
SPECIAL INSTRUCTIONS TO STUDENTS-Long Distance Collect calls incoming are not to be accepted from any source. A penalty of $5.00 will be assessed by the University for each collect toll call accepted by a student. 
IN MAKINGANY CALL BE SURE TO WAIT FOR DIAL TONE—DIAL EACH DIGIT CAREFULLY

Wc\t ^otrc 
The Honor Concept expresses in a single sentence the entire commitment of theNotre Dame student: 
“As a Notre Dame Student, I pledge honesty in all my academic work and will not tolerate dishonesty in my fellow students.” 
The Concept captures the meaning of the ideal of Honor, for it depends ultimately on the individual’s personal avowal of academic honesty, in face of all difficulties. Its development at the University is thus hindered by the lack of commitment to honesty on the part of some, and the lack of concern on the part of others. Yet the Concept, initiated by the students, faculty and administration together, is a common effort for acommon good andits growth is the responsibility of all. 
SCHOLASTIC  William Cullen  
239 Walsh  8095  
Office:  7569,7419  
SCIENCE  Robert J. Ursano  
QUARTERLY TECHNICAL REVIEW  138 Howard Albert Andry 428 Walsh  8179 8158  
UNIVERSITY  David Breen  
DIRECTORY  725 E. Angela Blvd. Nancy Tavery 386 LeMans Hall  232-8552 4627  
WSND  John Sturm  
AM 6400  203 Walsh  8050  
FM 7342  Office:  7425  

jMmtor (Emttepi 
A functioning Honor Concept can be not only a source of pride in itself to the University, but also a means to the attainment of ideals of individual and university life. Since it confronts the individual with the challenge to be honest with himself and with others, it lays open the opportunity to attain a new level in human dignity. Since an individual student cannot realistically accept the value ofhonesty unless itisvery nature, unites all students into a community bound together bycommitment to honesty. Finally, since the Honor Concept cannot function without the authority of the faculty and administration in academic matters, nor without their support of the student effort, it implies acloser understanding, mutual trust, and mutual respect among the elements of the Notre Dame community. 
The Student Honor Council 
Rectors,

August 25—October 27,1968 art-objects. The combined efforts of the Metropolitan Museum ot 
Art and Mr. and Mrs. Lester Wolfe will make up the loans for this THE CHANGE OF PERCEPTION, THE PERCEPTION OF exhibit. CHANGE. Under the sponsorship of the United Church of Christ Conference at Notre Dame, this exhibit juxtaposes themes and January 5—February 23,1969 styles in paintings, graphics, and sculpture, illustrating contrast and variety in the history of art. The works are from the Art Gallery’s PAINTINGS FROM THE BAKER COLLECTION. Keenly respons­
ive to subtle variations and movements within contemporary permanent collection. 
endeavors, Richard Brown Baker collects a wide representation of examples which bring out variety and contrast. The exhibition will 
November 3-December 29,1968 include paintings and sculpture by such artists as Jasper Johns, EGYPTIAN ART. For the first time in its recent history the Art Robert Rauschenbert, Claes Oldenberg, Victor Vasarely, Richard Gallery will present a large group of Egyptian Sculpture and Anuskiewicz, and DavidSmith. 
March 2March 
—April 13, 1969 

THE AGE OF VASARI. After two years of anticipation by scholars and critics, this major exhibition will stress the characteristics ofthe provocative 16th century school of painting and sculpture, the Mannersits. The show, filling both sides of the gallery, will feature masterpieces from numerous American and European collections. 
April 20—June 29, 1969 

RECENT ACQUISITIONS. It has been three years since the University brought together a large grouping of recent acquisitions to the permanent collection. There have been notableadditions and the best of these willbe selected for the current show. 
July 1—October 15, 1969 

THE MADONNA AND CHILD IN ROMANESQUE ART. Mr. Eric DeKolb has kindly and generously consented to lend his large collection of Romanesque sculpture to NotreDame for the Summer of 1969. This will include many images from France and Spain of the 12th Century or near that time, all of which depict the Virgin Mary and her Child. 
EAST GALLERY 
September 15—November 3,1968 

CONTEMPORARY PRINTS. Mr. William J. Plunkett, a dealer in 
contemporary prints, has kindly consented to lend Notre Dame a 
significant group of graphics done by artists working in England, 
France, and the United States. 
November 10—December 29, 1968 

DON VOGL. A faculty member of the Notre Dame Art Depart­ment, Don Vogl continues to develop style through his work in painting and graphics. Currently on leave, this exhibition represents some of his most recentwork. 
January 12-February 23,1969 

STILL LIFE FROMTHEPERMANENT COLLECTION. One of the oldest traditions in art, still life, or nature mort is still lively in our time, though it takes new directions. This exhibition is planned to show the contrast. Earlier painters might faithfully copy the object. The painter of today might merely stick a photograph ofthe object on his painting and do little further to it. 
KONSTANTIN MILONADIS. The distinguished artist in residence at Notre Dame continues to attract wide attention through his kinetic constructions. His works reflect the rapid changes in our technological world of mobility, and more whimsically might be called “Icons of a Scientific Age.” 
April 27—June 8, 1969 

STUDENT EXHIBITION. This selection of paintings, drawings, graphics and sculpture is a review exhibition for graduating seniors and graduate students. 
June 15—July 30, 1969 

ONE CENT LIFE. The ARt Gallery of Ball State University has kindly loaned this group of lithographs. The poet, Walasse Ting, friend of many contemporary artists, planned this group of exciting lithographs that unite the image with verse. 
LECTURES 

October 15,1968: 
AMERICAN ART SINCE 1900, Harry Greaver, Director, Kalama­zoo Institute of Arts. 
February 12,1969: 
DIRECTIONS IN CONTEMPORARY ART. James McGarrell, Resi­dent artist, Indiana University. 
March, 1969: (Specific dates to be announced): 
LECTURES ON THE MANNERISTS, Dr. Irving Zupnick, Professor of Art History, State University of New York, Binghamton, N.Y. 
Janos Scholz, Musician and Collector of Italian drawings, New York. 
Dean A. Porter, Curator of Art Gallery at the University of Notre Dame. 
July 15, 1969: 

ROMANESQUE SCULPTORS AND THEIR WORK, Rev. Anthony 
J. Lauck, C.S.C., Director, Art Gallery at the University of Notre Dame
